Motion
3. Motion

Again the proper subject matter of physics is body inasmuch as it is
movable. We have just looked at Avicenna’s conception of body
and associated issues. I now turn to his theory of motion, followed by
discussions of some of the conditions necessary for motion, like time
and place. Avicenna’s theory of motion is best understood
against the background of Aristotle’s account of motion and
developments surrounding that account that emerged in the later Greek
world. (For detailed discussions of Avicenna’s theory of motion
see Hasnawi 2001; McGinnis 2006a; and Ahmed 2016).
